title: 108_hr931
content: The "National Language Act of 2003" establishes English as the official language of the government. The "National Language Act of 2003" declares English as the official language of the United States government for all official activities and materials. It aims to preserve and enhance the role of English as the official language, with limited exceptions specified by law. The "National Language Act of 2003" establishes English as the official language of the United States government, with exceptions for religious purposes, foreign language training, language programs in schools, and individuals over 62 years old. The Act does not create a legal entitlement to services in languages other than English. SEC. 3. TERMINATION OF BILINGUAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS. The Bilingual Education Act is repealed, the Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Languages Affairs is terminated, unexpended funds will be recaptured, and transitional provisions are in place for current programs. The Bilingual Education Act is repealed, and transitional provisions are in place for current programs to assist in the transition of children to Special Alternative Instructional Programs. The Bilingual Education Act is repealed, including bilingual voting requirements. The Bilingual Education Act, including bilingual voting requirements, is repealed. Section 203 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is repealed, and Section 4 is amended by removing subsection (f). Conforming amendments are made to references to Section 203 and Section 4 in the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended by removing subsection (f) and making changes to various paragraphs in section 4(a) related to guarantees of voting rights. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require all citizenship ceremonies to be conducted in English. This Act does not preempt any state laws.
